clinical_study.brief_title: Mirtazapine for the Treatment of Methamphetamine Dependence Among MSM (M2.0)
clinical_study.official_title: Mirtazapine for the Treatment of Methamphetamine Dependence Among MSM: a 6-month Randomized Controlled Trial With 3 Months of Follow-up
clinical_study.source: San Francisco Department of Public Health

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators recently conducted a double-blind, randomized controlled trial (n=60) of limited duration (12 weeks), and found that compared with placebo, oral mirtazapine, an FDA-approved antidepressant, significantly reduced meth use in those receiving mirtazapine, as determined by reduction in meth-positive urines. Sexual risk behaviors also declined significantly in the mirtazapine arm compared to placebo. Mirtazapine decreased meth use despite low adherence: by medical event monitoring system (MEMS) caps, only 48.5% of daily doses were taken. All participants received weekly substance use counseling and monthly, brief clinician-delivered adherence counseling. The investigators propose expanding upon these results by lengthening the treatment period to 24 weeks, with adherence reminders added to the counseling, and determining if efficacy is sustained up to 12 weeks after drug discontinuation. The sample size for this 9-month study is 120.

primary_outcome.description: To determine the efficacy of mirtazapine vs placebo at 12 weeks and 24 weeks of treatment plus counseling, and to determine whether efficacy is sustained for an additional 12 weeks after discontinuation of treatment and counseling (weeks 24 to 36).

secondary_outcome.description: To assess if the intervention reduces HIV risk behaviors, including number of male sex partners, number of male anal sex partners with whom meth is used and episodes of unprotected anal sex with serodiscordant partners.

other_outcome.description: To measure the acceptability of mirtazapine and placebo by determining (via electronic pill boxes and self-report) medication adherence including percent of doses taken, taking less than 80% of medication, patterns of non-adherence (e.g. use every other day, during the weekend, longer alternating periods on and off medication), and time to stopping medication.
To measure the tolerability of mirtazapine and placebo, as determined by the number of adverse clinical events in the mirtazapine and placebo arms.
